**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 28**.proposition: Under **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, orders concerning custody or parenting time may be modified upon a showing of a **material and substantial change in circumstances** and that modification would serve the **best interests of the child**.

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, \u00a7 20**.proposition: The Plaintiff, **Jessica Thompson** (“Mother”), brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20**, and **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, § 6**, seeking modification of the existing custody and parenting order entered by this Court on **June 15, 2019**.

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, \u00a7 6**.proposition: The Plaintiff, **Jessica Thompson** (“Mother”), brings this Complaint for Modification pursuant to **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 28**, **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 209C, § 20**, and **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 215, § 6**, seeking modification of the existing custody and parenting order entered by this Court on **June 15, 2019**.

**Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, \u00a7 31**.proposition: Further, under **Mass. Gen. Laws ch. 208, § 31**, both parents share responsibility for promoting the child’s welfare, and parenting plans must reflect realistic logistics supporting consistent schooling and rest.

*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 [1996.proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has consistently held that a substantial change in either parent’s circumstances—such as a relocation—may justify modification of custody orders (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 [1996]; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 [2003]).
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 [1996.support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn concerns how courts must account for domestic violence and its effects on children when making or reviewing custody determinations. It does not address modification of existing custody orders, the legal standard for modification, or relocation as a form of substantial change in circumstances. Accordingly, it does not provide authority for the proposition that a substantial change such as relocation may justify modification of custody orders.
*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 [1996.relevant_excerpt: We agree with the Appeals Court that the judge below “fail[ed] to make detailed and comprehensive findings of fact on the issues of domestic violence and its effect upon the child as well as upon the father’s parenting ability.” … Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. The very frequency of domestic violence in disputes about child custody may have the effect of inuring courts to it and thus minimizing its significance.

*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 [2003].proposition: The Supreme Judicial Court has consistently held that a substantial change in either parent’s circumstances—such as a relocation—may justify modification of custody orders (*Custody of Vaughn*, 422 Mass. 590 [1996]; *Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 [2003]).
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 [2003].support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Kali is not a modification case and does not discuss or apply the “substantial change in circumstances” standard as a basis for modifying an existing custody order due to relocation or any other change. Instead, the SJC explicitly declines to reach the father’s argument that a substantial-change standard under G.L. c. 209C, § 20 should apply, holding that the case was tried as an initial custody determination under the best-interests standard in § 10(a) and that any § 20 arguments were waived. Thus, it does not establish that a substantial change in either parent’s circumstances may justify modification of custody orders.
*Custody of Kali*, 439 Mass. 834 [2003].relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20… The father’s arguments … were not made to the probate judge and are waived.”

*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.proposition: The “best interests of the child” remain paramount in all custody determinations (*Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 [1985]; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 [2001]; *Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [1991]).
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that in removal and custody matters, the best interests of the child are the paramount concern, and interprets the governing statute to require that removal be in the child’s best interests. The opinion then applies that standard in determining physical custody and permission to remove the children to Greece, confirming that the child’s best interests control the analysis even while considering the parents’ interests.
*Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas*, 395.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that… ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child… and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern, ‘[b]ecause the best interests of a child are so interwoven with the well-being of the custodial parent, the determination of the child’s best interest requires that the interests of the custodial parent be taken into account.’”

*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: The “best interests of the child” remain paramount in all custody determinations (*Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 [1985]; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 [2001]; *Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [1991]).
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion expressly states that in removal cases "the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern" and applies that standard in conjunction with the Yannas real‑advantage framework. It also reiterates, in the custody‑modification discussion, that modification must be "necessary in the best interests of the children," confirming that the child’s best interests control custody determinations. Thus, Rosenthal directly supports the proposition that the best interests of the child remain paramount in custody decisions.
*Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “A request for removal is governed by G. L. c. 208, § 30, as that statute has been interpreted by Yannas… and Hale… A parent’s request to relocate with a child from the Commonwealth must be ‘grounded on the “realization that after a divorce a child’s subsequent relationship with both parents can never be the same as before the divorce … [and] that the child’s quality of life and style of life are provided by the custodial parent.” Although the best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern…’”

*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [199.proposition: The “best interests of the child” remain paramount in all custody determinations (*Yannas v. Frondistou‑Yannas*, 395 Mass. 704 [1985]; *Rosenthal v. Maney*, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 [2001]; *Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [1991]).
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [199.support_reasoning: The court explicitly states that under G. L. c. 208, § 30 the controlling standard for removal is the child’s best interests, and that this standard cannot be displaced by a separation agreement. It emphasizes that the Probate Court may disregard contractual terms where the welfare of the child warrants it, making clear that the child’s best interests are paramount in custody/removal determinations.
*Williams v. Pitney*, 409 Mass. 449 [199.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, and the standard of proof which it requires cannot be written off by the parties. The best interests of the child will control where there is a question as to whether the child will be removed from the Commonwealth. The jurisdiction of the Probate Court over the minor children of divorced parties may not be ousted by the terms of a separation agreement, and the court may, where the best interests of the child dictate, disregard the agreement.”

*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court recognizes that parenting plans must be practical and must not unreasonably disrupt a child’s daily routine or education (*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 [2006]; *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 [1981]).
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.support_reasoning: Pizzino is a removal case focused on the Yannas ‘real advantage’ test and the best interests analysis in the context of interstate relocation. While the court mentions schooling, housing, transitions, and family separation as factors in the best-interests inquiry, it does not articulate any general rule that “parenting plans must be practical” or that they “must not unreasonably disrupt a child’s daily routine or education.” The opinion thus addresses broader best-interest factors, not the specific practical-parenting-plan principle stated in the proposition.
*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 8.relevant_excerpt: “In determining a child’s best interests, consideration must be given ‘to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life), the possible adverse effect of the elimination or curtailment of the child’s association with the noncustodial parent, and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.’ Yannas, 395 Mass. at 711.”

*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.proposition: The Massachusetts Appeals Court recognizes that parenting plans must be practical and must not unreasonably disrupt a child’s daily routine or education (*Pizzino v. Miller*, 67 Mass. App. Ct. 865 [2006]; *Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 [1981]).
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.support_reasoning: Rolde focuses on best interests of the child, joint vs. sole custody, and the parents’ ability to cooperate, but it does not expressly discuss the need for parenting plans to be practical in the sense of avoiding unreasonable disruption of a child’s daily routine or education. The court notes the importance of minimizing disruption and fostering a healthy environment, but that is in the context of choosing between joint and sole custody, not evaluating the structure or logistics of a parenting plan. Thus, it only indirectly relates to, and does not clearly establish, the specific proposition claimed.
*Rolde v. Rolde*, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398.relevant_excerpt: “The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

*Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 479.proposition: Courts also find that evidence of fatigue, academic disruption, or significant travel burden on a child can justify withdrawing midweek overnights (*Macri v. Macri*, 96 Mass. App. Ct. 479 [2019]).

*Hassett v. Hassett*, 80 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: In addition, *Hassett v. Hassett*, 80 Mass. App. Ct. 515 (2011), confirms that relocation substantially affecting a child’s schooling and well‑being satisfies the “material change” requirement for modification.
*Hassett v. Hassett*, 80 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The provided text from Hassett is a criminal case dissent focused on competency to stand trial, waiver of counsel, and the right to proceed pro se. It does not involve family law, custody, relocation, or modification standards, nor does it discuss “material change” in the context of a child’s schooling or well‑being. Accordingly, this opinion does not support the claimed proposition about relocation satisfying a material change requirement for modification.
*Hassett v. Hassett*, 80 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: "Competency. Prior to trial, the defendant had three competency evaluations and one hearing and was repeatedly found competent; at the beginning of the trial, the judge again assessed the defendant’s competency in a colloquy to waive counsel; during the four-day jury trial, the defendant represented himself and presented not a scintilla of behavior indicative of any competency problems; and, lastly, at no point did standby counsel ever alert the judge to any competency concerns."

*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: *Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006), explains that where compliance with an existing parenting plan has become detrimental due to increased travel or changed living situations, modification is appropriate.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns standards for removal of children from the Commonwealth in a joint physical custody situation, not modification of a parenting plan due to increased travel or changed living situations. While it notes that relocation can be a substantial change in circumstances and that increased travel burdens may affect best interests, the holding is focused on denying removal and continuing shared custody, not on explaining that modification is appropriate when compliance with an existing plan becomes detrimental. Thus, the case does not affirm the specific proposition stated.
*Mason v. Coleman*, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “It is a question for a judge, taking into account all of the facts, whether an increase in travel time between households and schools brought about by removal, and other burdens of distance, will significantly impair either parent’s ability to exercise existing responsibilities, and ultimately whether removal is in a child’s best interests.”

*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: *Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012), emphasizes that stability and continuity in school and daily life are essential components of the best‑interest analysis.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion’s best‑interest analysis expressly identifies stability of living arrangements and continuity in caregiving and schedule as key factors a judge may weigh. The court then applies those principles to compare each parent’s stability, number of moves and caregivers, and work schedules in deciding that primary physical custody should go to Hunter. This directly affirms that stability and continuity in daily life are essential components of the best‑interest inquiry.
*Hunter v. Rose*, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “The judge shall consider ‘whether or not the child’s present or past living conditions adversely affect his physical, mental, moral or emotional health.’ G. L. c. 208, § 31. Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. See Adoption of Kali, supra at 843, 847 (stability and flexible work schedule)… In addition to weighing these factors, the judge also assessed the stability each parent offered Jill, as well as the flexibility of each parent’s job.”
